title: Drinking water cross-over module
description: The "Drinking Water" course is about: winning, storing, distributing, purifying and improving our drinking water. And also about the use and value of drinking water. This cross-over course can serve well as a starting point for project-based work. A correction model is attached.  The course material is intended for lower secondary education.

items.content:
You're opening the tap and there is water. You will find that quite common. However, there are many things involved to make this possible. This is what this module is about: winning, save, distribute, purify and improve our drinking water, and also about the use and value of drinking water.

Question: Where does our drinking water come from and how do we deal with it?

In this module you will work on learning objectives of the learning areas:social sciences, science and technology, arithmetic, math and English.

Method: you answer the questions in this module individually. The interim products and the final product you will make with a group. For some answers you have to search on the internet. As a result, you will work on the 21st century skills: teamwork, critical thinking, Information skills and media literacy. At the unit end products and the final assignment we also require creativity of you.

Learning units
The module consists of 5 learning units and a final assignment.
The time per learning unit is approximately:

Where does drinking water come from? 3 hrs
Does water only consist of water? 2,5 hrs
Use of drinking water 2,5 hrs
Water and technology 2 hrs
The value of water 3 hrs
Final assignment 7 hrs

In the learning object Planning you will make a planning in which you indicate when you are going to spend this time and with whom you work together.

At the end of the module in the learning object Evaluation you look back on the module.
As a result, you will work on the learning strategies: planning and evaluation.

heading.content: Where does drinking water come from?

items.content:
For convenience we use the term drinking water for all the water that is used in households. We actually mean tap water. Tap water consists of the water we drink, of hot water and of household water. But where does this drinking water actually come from?

Learning objectives
In this learning unit, you will work on the learning objectives:

  • Describe the cycle of water
  • Presenting
  • Use lay-out elements in documents
  • Creativity
  • Collaboration

Assignment
At the end of this learning unit you make a poster about water scarcity (groups of 2).

Time
For this learning unit you have 3 hours of which 1 hour for making the final poster.

prompt.body:
For convenience we call all the water that is used in households drinking water. We actually mean tap water there. Tap water is made up of the water we drink, from hot tap water and out household water.

  • Drinking water comes from the tap in most homes. In the vast majority of houses it is also used, for example, to shower or to flush the toilet. Purified by the water company, the water is so clean, that it is suitable for consumption.
  • Warm tap water is sometimes provided, for example to shower. This applies to water that is centrally heated for some houses (blocks) at the same time. Sometimes it is delivered by energy distribution companies. In other cases the owner of the apartment complex will be responsible for this. The domestic warm tap water is subject to the same quality requirements as for drinking water.
  • Household water is not clean enough for consumption, but is for flushing the toilet, doing the laundry, or for watering the garden. This water is provided through a separate piping system.

Find out why there is no use made of separate household water in the households?

values.value: Household water can be a health hazard, resulting in epidemics. A separate pipeline network is required for the distribution of household water. After a few incidents with the supply of household water (including incorrect connections), it was decided to no longer allow the large-scale supply of household water by water companies. Only in specific small-scale cases can the use of domestic water for toilet flushing remain possible.

content.body: Household water can be a health hazard, resulting in epidemics. A separate pipeline network is required for the distribution of household water. After a few incidents with the supply of household water (including incorrect connections), it was decided to no longer allow the large-scale supply of household water by water companies. Only in specific small-scale cases can the use of domestic water for toilet flushing remain possible.

heading.content: Step 2 - The long and the short cycle

header.title: The long and the short cycle

prompt.body:
Earth's water is constantly on the go. Via rivers, canals and streams but also under the ground it flows from the mountains to the sea. There evaporates by the warmth of the Sun. The vapor rises up and forms a cloud. That is driven by the wind from all sides. As the clouds at high altitude, where it is colder, the water vapor cools and falls as rain, snow or hail down. The most rain water comes right back in the sea. The rest falls on the country and disappears in the ground or through rivers and canals to the sea. The same happens with the snow that falls on the mountains. The water that evaporates back into the sea, again by the warmth of the Sun, forming a cloud that is driven by the wind in all directions, cools off again and so on. This way the water time and again, we call the long cycle.

Make according to description above a drawing of the long cycle.
Upload your drawing.

values.value: Drawing to be judged by the teacher. Your teacher might indicate in advance which criteria (minimum requirements) the drawing must meet. Sample drawing:

content.body: Drawing to be judged by the teacher. Your teacher might indicate in advance which criteria (minimum requirements) the drawing must meet. Sample drawing:

prompt.body:
Sometimes the water arrives, after a little detour, in the same place again. The water makes a smaller circle. We are talking of the short cycle. For example, if the water as rain falls into the sea, evaporates through the sun, converts into a rain cloud and falls down as rain into the sea again.
Think of another short cycle.
Make a drawing of it. Describe what is happening with the water in this short cycle.
Upload your drawing with the description

values.value:
Your example and your drawing will be judged by the teacher on creativity and correctness

In a short cycle, the water returns to the same place after a small detour.

For example:
a farmer sprays his land with a spraying machine in the summer. The machine pumps the water out of a ditch and sprays it on the land. Part of that water sinks into the ground and flows back underground to the ditch. Another part evaporates due to the heat from the sun. The vapor rises upwards and forms a cloud. When the cloud is at high altitude the water vapor cools down and falls into the ditch again as rain.

content.body:
Your example and your drawing will be judged by the teacher on creativity and correctness

In a short cycle, the water returns to the same place after a small detour.

For example:
a farmer sprays his land with a spraying machine in the summer. The machine pumps the water out of a ditch and sprays it on the land. Part of that water sinks into the ground and flows back underground to the ditch. Another part evaporates due to the heat from the sun. The vapor rises upwards and forms a cloud. When the cloud is at high altitude the water vapor cools down and falls into the ditch again as rain.

heading.content: Step 3 - Where does drinking water come from?

items.content:
Drinking water in the UK is made from surface water (two thirds) and groundwater (one thirds). Groundwater is rain water that has sunk deep-between 40 and 300 meter- in the ground. It is naturally filtered, but it should still be treated before it is suitable as drinking water.

The amount of water available in England and Wales to meet the needs of people and to sustain the water environment varies greatly between different places and seasons, and from one year to another. Parts of Wales and the English Lake District are well endowed with water, while water is scarce in parts of Eastern and Southeastern England. Parts of England were affected by severe drought in 1976, 1995 and 2005-2007.

Surface water is dirtier than groundwater. Therefore, the cleaning process is more extensive and more expensive, and that makes the drinking water from surface water more expensive.

Key words: groundwater extraction, surface water, infiltration

heading.content: Step 4 - Will sewage water become drinking water again?

header.title: Will sewage water become drinking water again?

questions.label: Will sewage water become drinking water again?

prompt.body:
You go to the toilet and do a pee. Your urine is conducted by a drain pipe to the sewer. If sewer water is really used to produce drinking water, your pee becomes drinking water after some time! Is this really true......?
The dishwater of the dishes, the water from the washing machine, the water used when showering and cooking disappear just like the flush water from the toilet as waste water runs into the sewer system. Do we produce drinking water from this water as well? Yes, we turn it into drinking water!

Consider how sewage water is converted in drinking water.
Describe how this is done according to the following sketch.
Use between 70 and 100 words for your description.

values.value: Sewage water is treated in a sewage treatment plant. The treated water is discharged as surface water on a stream, river or canal. The water companies make fresh drinking water again from water from a river or canal. It is also possible that a part of the purified sewage water sinks into the soil. The water that falls into the soil is sooner or later pumped up again as groundwater. The water company makes drinking water again. Sewage water can, after treatment, ever become drinking water again.

content.body: Sewage water is treated in a sewage treatment plant. The treated water is discharged as surface water on a stream, river or canal. The water companies make fresh drinking water again from water from a river or canal. It is also possible that a part of the purified sewage water sinks into the soil. The water that falls into the soil is sooner or later pumped up again as groundwater. The water company makes drinking water again. Sewage water can, after treatment, ever become drinking water again.

heading.content: Step 5 – Why is seawater (usually) not converted into drinking water?

header.title: Why is seawater (usually) not converted into drinking water?

questions.label: Why is seawater (usually) not converted into drinking water?

prompt.body:
Seventy % of the Earth's surface consists of sea water. It would be marvellous if we could drink this water and could water the land with it. There would be no water shortages anymore and many bone dry piece of Earth could be made fertile.
Unfortunately, we cannot produce (enough) drinking water from seawater.

Why can't we make (enough) drinking water of seawater?

Keywords: desalting plants, desalination methods, (solar)distillation.

values.value: We have succeeded in making drinking water from seawater. But  we have not yet succeeded in developing a cheap method. Water factories devour a lot of fuel and that makes desalinating water very expensive. Solar distillation seems cheaper, as a desalination method, because solar heat is free. But the yield is low. And newer techniques do not offer a solution yet. Thousands of desalination plants worldwide produce more than 13 billion liters of fresh water per day. That looks like an impressive number. But it is only one and a half percent of all the drinking and domestic water that all people around the world need every day.

content.body: We have succeeded in making drinking water from seawater. But we have not yet succeeded in developing a cheap method. Water factories devour a lot of fuel and that makes desalinating water very expensive. Solar distillation seems cheaper, as a desalination method, because solar heat is free. But the yield is low. And newer techniques do not offer a solution yet. Thousands of desalination plants worldwide produce more than 13 billion liters of fresh water per day. That looks like an impressive number. But it is only one and a half percent of all the drinking and domestic water that all people around the world need every day.

questions.label: What happens if we all drink all sea water?

prompt.body:
Making sea water drinkable will become affordable someday. But then again we are not there yet.

But what happens if we all drink al the seawater....?

values.value: Although we are with many people in the world, and even if they drink all the sea water, the sea is not yet empty. Water that is used always comes back in one way or another. We will never succeed in emptying the sea!

content.body: Although we are with many people in the world, and even if they drink all the sea water, the sea is not yet empty. Water that is used always comes back in one way or another. We will never succeed in emptying the sea!

questions.label: What is a Drinking water safeguard zone?

prompt.body:
You might find that there is a Drinking water safeguard zone near the area where you live?

But what is a Drinking water safeguard zone and what needs to be safeguarded?

values.value:
Drinking water safeguard zones are designated areas in which the use of certain substances must be carefully managed to prevent th pollution of raw water sources that are used to provide drinking water.


In order to protect our water we want to ensure that we are not polluting it with additional substances leading to the need for more treatment. To do this we identify Safeguard Zones for any raw water sources that are ‘at risk’ of deterioration which would result in the need for additional treatment. These zones are areas where the land use is causing pollution of the raw water. Action is targeted in these zones to address pollution so that extra treatment of raw water can be avoided.

content.body:
Drinking water safeguard zones are designated areas in which the use of certain substances must be carefully managed to prevent th pollution of raw water sources that are used to provide drinking water.


In order to protect our water we want to ensure that we are not polluting it with additional substances leading to the need for more treatment. To do this we identify Safeguard Zones for any raw water sources that are 'at risk' of deterioration which would result in the need for additional treatment. These zones are areas where the land use is causing pollution of the raw water. Action is targeted in these zones to address pollution so that extra treatment of raw water can be avoided.

prompt.body:
When we look at our Planet Earth from space, we see a ' blue planet '. 70% of the Earth's surface is covered with water. If the Earth would be completely flat, then it would be one Sea, 3,700 meters deep. An inexhaustible source, so it seems. But 97% of the 1.4 billion cubic kilometres of water is sea water, and more than 2% is ice. What remains is either at great depths, or is highly polluted. This means that only 0.003% would be immediately suitable to be used for the supply of drinking water.

It seems logical that this raw material should be estimated to its value, protected and safeguarded for future generations. Yet this is not done sufficiently. Water is still being wasted, polluted and ' abused '. This causes an impending global water scarcity. Recent forecasts suggest that by 2025 more than fifty countries, with three billion people will face water scarcity, caused by an increase in the demand for water with 650%.

We live today thanks to the presence of water. All life on our planet, after all, has emerged from the water. The importance of this natural raw material is still increasing: the presence of (potable) water determines the social and cultural structure and the level of development of a country. Often, water is a power tool, a weapon that determines economic strength and political relations within a group of countries, a region or a continent.
If we continue to follow the current tendency, in the future we will no longer have access to sufficient drinking water.

  • Create (in pairs) a poster in which you explain 5 causes of water scarcity and prepare a presentation of the poster.
  • You agree with your teacher when you two will present the poster.
  • Your poster and presentation are judged on content, language and presentation.

The assessment of language and presentation is developed further in this form.

values.value:
1. Desiccation or exhaustion

In recent years there has been growing fear of a possible dehydration or depletion of our water resources. However, water is not scarce in the world. As a result of natural phenomena or through the intervention of man, the water shortage is always time-bound. The extent to which water is consumed and the extent to which existing water resources can supplement at the same time are the two basic parameters.

2. Population growth

The growing world population is putting additional pressure on water resources; not only because of rising water consumption but also due to the associated ecological phenomena. Between 1940 and 1990 the world population grew by more than 100%; from 2.3 billion to 5.3 billion. At the same time, water consumption doubled per person. As a result of these two elements, global water consumption quadrupled over a period of half a century.

3. The 'greenhouse effect'

The real consequences of the gradual warming (due to CO2 emissions) of our planet are impossible to foresee. Implications for existing ecosystems are, however, inevitable. The climate changes and changes the existing weather conditions. The consequences of this can be drastic: droughts, floods, etc. The management of local water resources and the management of the water systems must, with a view to survival, be thoroughly and urgently adapted to the new circumstances.

4. Pollution

The pressure on existing water resources is high; not in the least because of the increasing pollution. This has many causes: residues from industry and agriculture, insufficient or absent wastewater treatment plants. The figures on this are staggering: half of the world's population suffers from diseases that are directly or indirectly due to the use of polluted water. These diseases kill 5 million people each year, including 4 in 5 children in developing countries.

5. Incompetent or incorrect use

Despite frequent campaigns, water consumption in our modern world continues to rise. Of course, these increases are not only encouraged by domestic use; consumption also increased significantly in agriculture and industry. The way in which one consumes and the size of the consumption is directly dependent on the level of economic development, the climate and the population size, and therefore differ from country to country or from region to region. Inhabitants of the African continent devote almost 88 percent of their water resources to irrigation in agriculture, while Europeans reserve half of the available water for industrial applications and the production of hydroelectricity. Language and content: assessment form.

heading.content: Does water only consist of water?

items.content:
Drinking water can be different everywhere. It can vary in taste, smell, colour, composition and ' be hard ' or ' soft '. What makes drinking water so different?

Learning objectives

In this learning unit, you will work on the learning objectives:

  • Describe what substances can be found in drinking water
  • Cooperation
  • Critical thinking
  • Information skills
  • Internationalization

Assignment

At the end of this learning unit you will make in groups of 3 an info-graphic about the quality of water in the different countries of Europe.

heading.content: Step 1 - Is there anything else than water in water?

header.title: Is there anything else than water in water?

questions.label: Is there anything else than water in water?

prompt.body:
Yes. In addition to water (H2O) drinking water contains natural minerals and metals such as copper, iron, selenium and chrome, but also bacteria like coliform and streptococcal. Maximum values for substances and micro-organisms in drinking water are determined in the Water Supply (Water Quality) Regulations in order to protect the public health.

Water is sometimes described as H2O.
Where are the letters H and O for?
And what does that 2 mean?
Search term: chemical elements

values.value: Water is described as H2O. This means that a molecule of water consists of 2 atoms of hydrogen (= H) and one atom of oxygen (= O). The number indicates the number of atoms. The number 1 is omitted (at O).

content.body: Water is described as H2O. This means that a molecule of water consists of 2 atoms of hydrogen (= H) and one atom of oxygen (= O). The number indicates the number of atoms. The number 1 is omitted (at O).

heading.content: Step 2 - Which quality requirements apply to drinking water?

header.title: Which quality requirements apply to drinking water?

questions.label: Which quality requirements apply to drinking water?

prompt.body:
Tap water should not be a risk to public health. That is a broad concept, which is worked out further in the "The Water Supply (Water Quality) Regulations. Here you can find also specific requirements for drinking- and hot tap water. These standards are established by DEFRA, in consultation with the water companies and partly on the basis of advice from for example the World Health Organisation and the Environment agency. The directive which the European Union has drawn up for the drinking water, is also integrated into UK law.


The above piece of text contains "DEFRA".


What do these letters stand for?

values.value: Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs

content.body: Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs

heading.content: Step 3 – Why does water taste differently in different cities?

introduction.body:
Taste and colour of drinking water depend on the type of water from which it is made and how it is purified to make it suitable for consumption. There are rules for the taste and the colour of the water. These are standards for materials that are not harmful to health, but can cause changes to the colour or taste of drinking water. It concerns substances such as iron and manganese.
Answer the following questions.

prompt.body:
The drinking water could have a light yellow glow in some parts of the country.
Find out how this is caused?
(For example: contact a water company)

values.value: The slightly yellow glow in the drinking water is caused by peat layers in the soil.

content.body: The slightly yellow glow in the drinking water is caused by peat layers in the soil.

prompt.body: Sometimes the tap water comes out brown. Find out how this can occur?

values.value:
Brown water contains iron and manganese.

Iron and manganese are for the most part removed from the water using filters. A very small amount passes through the filters and settles into the mains. Under normal circumstances you do not notice anything about this and these substances are not harmful to health. When the flow rate in the pipeline network suddenly increases or changes direction (for example during maintenance of the water mains), the substances can become turbid and the water becomes turbid. When the water flows again in the normal way, the substances adhere to the tube wall and the water becomes clear again.

content.body:
Brown water contains iron and manganese.

Iron and manganese are for the most part removed from the water using filters. A very small amount passes through the filters and settles into the mains. Under normal circumstances you do not notice anything about this and these substances are not harmful to health. When the flow rate in the pipeline network suddenly increases or changes direction (for example during maintenance of the water mains), the substances can become turbid and the water becomes turbid. When the water flows again in the normal way, the substances adhere to the tube wall and the water becomes clear again.

prompt.body: Water tastes sometimes like chlorine. Find out why chlorine is added to water sometimes?

values.value:
Chlorine kills pathogenic bacteria in the tap water.

For decades, chlorine has played an important role in water purification. After all, chlorine kills germs. It has also contributed to the reliability of drinking water produced from surface water. The use of chlorine, however, is strongly declining. Some water companies still use chlorine in the treatment of surface water, but only in very small quantities. In case of bacterial contamination in the water mains, which can occur suddenly due to a pipe rupture, chlorine is temporarily required to kill any pathogenic bacteria. In that case it is added in very small doses, which are absolutely not harmful to health.

content.body:
Chlorine kills pathogenic bacteria in the tap water.

For decades, chlorine has played an important role in water purification. After all, chlorine kills germs. It has also contributed to the reliability of drinking water produced from surface water. The use of chlorine, however, is strongly declining. Some water companies still use chlorine in the treatment of surface water, but only in very small quantities. In case of bacterial contamination in the water mains, which can occur suddenly due to a pipe rupture, chlorine is temporarily required to kill any pathogenic bacteria. In that case it is added in very small doses, which are absolutely not harmful to health.

prompt.body: Lime in drinking water can affect the taste. It is not harmful to health. Find out what function does lime have?

values.value:
Lime is good for our bones.

Lime in the drinking water can affect the taste, but it is not harmful to health.

content.body:
Lime is good for our bones.

Lime in the drinking water can affect the taste, but it is not harmful to health.

heading.content: Step 4 - What is the difference between ' hard ' and ' soft ' water?

header.title: What is the difference between  'hard' and 'soft' water?

prompt.body:
Water contains minerals like chalk, lime and mostly calcium and magnesium..
This is in one region in a higher extension than in the other, which is due to the type of water used for producing drinking water. If there is a lot of lime in the water you speak of ' hard ' water, otherwise it is called ' soft ' water. The water company can inform you about the hardness of the water.

Hard water has certain disadvantages
Mention some disadvantages

values.value: Hard water contains a lot of lime. The harder the water, the more scale is formed. For example on taps or shower tiles, but also on heating elements of the washing machine, boiler or kettle. The latter is detrimental to the energy consumption of those devices. More detergent is needed with hard water. Because of all these drawbacks, the water companies involved have taken measures to supply softer water.

content.body: Hard water contains a lot of lime. The harder the water, the more scale is formed. For example on taps or shower tiles, but also on heating elements of the washing machine, boiler or kettle. The latter is detrimental to the energy consumption of those devices. More detergent is needed with hard water. Because of all these drawbacks, the water companies involved have taken measures to supply softer water.

prompt.body: In a kettle or water boiler you often find boiler scale: What actually is boiler scale?

values.value: Boiler stone is lime that is in the water. It settles on the bottom of the kettle or the kettle.

content.body: Boiler stone is lime that is in the water. It settles on the bottom of the kettle or the kettle.

prompt.body:
Do you have ' hard ' or ' soft ' water at home?
How do you know?

values.value: If there is a lot of limescale, for example on taps or shower tiles, but also on heating elements of the washing machine, dishwasher, boiler or kettle you have 'hard' water at home. With hard water you also need more detergent. If a bar of soap, as it were, melts away in a soap dish, it indicates very soft water. Whether you have hard or soft water at home, you can request it from the water company that supplies the water.

content.body: If there is a lot of limescale, for example on taps or shower tiles, but also on heating elements of the washing machine, dishwasher, boiler or kettle you have 'hard' water at home. With hard water you also need more detergent. If a bar of soap, as it were, melts away in a soap dish, it indicates very soft water. Whether you have hard or soft water at home, you can request it from the water company that supplies the water.

prompt.body: In which unit is the hardness of water expressed?

values.value: Hardness is usually expressed as ‘mg/l as CaCO3’, it’s calculated as if all the calcium and magnesium were present only as calcium carbonate.

content.body: Hardness is usually expressed as 'mg/l as CaCO3', it's calculated as if all the calcium and magnesium were present only as calcium carbonate.

prompt.body:
What is the hardness of drinking water at home?

Keywords: water company, water hardness

values.value: You can request the hardness of the drinking water at your home at the water company that supplies the water. You can also find out via the internet.

content.body: You can request the hardness of the drinking water at your home at the water company that supplies the water. You can also find out via the internet.

prompt.body: Is hard water unhealthy?

values.value: Hard water is not unhealthy. On the contrary: calcium and magnesium are minerals that are important in building our bones. Everyone needs them.

content.body: Hard water is not unhealthy. On the contrary: calcium and magnesium are minerals that are important in building our bones. Everyone needs them.

prompt.body:
Drinking water contains nitrate.
Why is there nitrate in our drinking water?

values.value:
Nitrate comes from manure.

Through fertilization of soil it ends up in the groundwater and eventually in our drinking water. The limit value of nitrate in drinking water is 50 milligrams per liter of drinking water. At that value, nitrate is not harmful to health. An excess is taken out by the water companies.

content.body:
Nitrate comes from manure.

Through fertilization of soil it ends up in the groundwater and eventually in our drinking water. The limit value of nitrate in drinking water is 50 milligrams per liter of drinking water. At that value, nitrate is not harmful to health. An excess is taken out by the water companies.

prompt.body:
Water also contains bacteria.
So is water really healthy?

values.value: Everywhere are bacteria, so also in water. These bacteria occur in extremely small quantities, that they are absolutely no danger to health. Although there are bacteria in the drinking water, it is still healthy.

content.body: Everywhere are bacteria, so also in water. These bacteria occur in extremely small quantities, that they are absolutely no danger to health. Although there are bacteria in the drinking water, it is still healthy.

prompt.body:
Drinking water also contains metals.
Name some metals in drinking water.

values.value: Drinking water contains metals such as copper, iron, selenium and chromium. DEFRA has set maximum values ​​for the substances that may occur in the drinking water in the interest of the protection of public health.

content.body: Drinking water contains metals such as copper, iron, selenium and chromium. DEFRA has set maximum values ​​for the substances that may occur in the drinking water in the interest of the protection of public health.

prompt.body: Is bottled water healthier than tap water?

values.value: Tap water is just as healthy as bottled water. UK legislation stipulates that the water companies must supply reliable drinking water. The water must therefore have no properties that can be bad for health. Among other things, fluorine, lead, chlorine and nitrate are substances that are not allowed to be in the drinking water or to a very limited extent. There is therefore no reason to drink water other than tap water. Some manufacturers of mineral waters sometimes claim that many or no minerals are good for the body. Minerals play an important role in specific body functions, but too many minerals are not good for the kidneys.

content.body: Tap water is just as healthy as bottled water. UK legislation stipulates that the water companies must supply reliable drinking water. The water must therefore have no properties that can be bad for health. Among other things, fluorine, lead, chlorine and nitrate are substances that are not allowed to be in the drinking water or to a very limited extent. There is therefore no reason to drink water other than tap water. Some manufacturers of mineral waters sometimes claim that many or no minerals are good for the body. Minerals play an important role in specific body functions, but too many minerals are not good for the kidneys.

prompt.body: Explain why bottled water is so expensive.

values.value: The bottled water itself is not expensive at all. The price of bottled water is determined by the manufacturer. He estimates how much the consumer is willing to pay for his water and how much money he has spent to put the water on the market. Think of the extraction of the water (pumping from the source), the purification of the water, the production of the packaging, the filling of the bottles or the packs, the transport, the labor costs and of course the promotion costs. And possibly the retrieval and purification of empty bottles. Then the seller of the water (shopkeeper, restaurant owner etc.) determines how much he asks for the water. The price of bottled water can therefore vary from less than one euro to over 8 euros per bottle!

items.content:
Without technology, we cannot have clean drinking water. The technique has enabled people over the centuries to gain water, store, distribute, purify and improve it.

Learning objectives

In this learning unit you will work on the learning objectives:

  • Describe production and distribution of drinking water
  • Describe and valuate measures for sustainable use of water

Time

For this learning unit you have 2 hours available.

heading.content: Step 1a - Water supply in the past

items.content:
The water supply as we know it today, is fairly recent; but its foundations go back many centuries. It is true that only in the last century we have made considerable progress. Yet one tries for centuries, in various ways, to store and distribute water.

The first primitive people were highly dependent on the natural conditions. They were going to live there where water was to be found. They settled on the edge of a river or in the vicinity of a natural spring. They discovered how water could be controlled.

About 7000 years ago, people discovered that one can find water by digging wells. Water was collected in water wells in Jericho and used as source for water. Wells of which the walls were lined with bamboo twigs, were found in Egypt. The water was picked up with buckets and leather pouches (shadoef). Already in that time, people started the building of waterlines through caving ditches from the rocks, or by digging trenches in the sand. Later the Egyptians used hollow palm trees for the construction of water conducts. In China, Java and Japan the made conduct out of bamboo.

The first kilometre-long supply pipe was in built in Pergamon, about 200 years before Christ. In ancient Greece they even built bridges to be able to cross valleys. The Greeks were therefore the first to supply water under high pressure using the principle of communicating vessels.

It was not until the Roman Empire that the water supply experienced a large growth. The basis for our current supply system was formed in this period. The sources for water were equipped in such a way that there was a maximum protection against contamination from outside. For example: the top of the gutter where the water flowed was covered with stones. It's mainly the aqueducts which still appeal to our imagination. Fourteen aqueducts carried water to Rome from where it was distributed over the different districts. Especially the rich, the thermal baths and the public fountains made use of this water supply system.
Apart from aqueducts, the Romans built also large pumps that that could pump water up.



After the collapse of the Roman Empire the aqueducts carried no more water for a long time. This caused the loss of the technical knowledge. The residents even had to hire carriers to bring water.

Later, in the middle-ages, nobody constructed water networks that could be compared to the Roman buildings. People were satisfied with getting water from wells, both in the city and beyond. Nevertheless the hygiene in this public wells was so bad, that regular epidemics such as the plague broke out. The wells were very simple in construction: the pick-up system consisted of a rope and a pulley. Because all the houses were built of wood, the risk of fire was very large. The well water was mainly used to fight fires and less as drinking water.

In order to encounter the pollution of drinking water, the wells were later covered and equipped with hand pumps.

Until the early twentieth century people brought their drinking water with a bucket from a stream or canal or from a well, also in our country. If they drank water, they got often an infectious disease such as typhoid fever or cholera. Because waste water and human waste were often discharged in the same stream or canal where the drinking water came from.

Improvement was very slow, with little effective progress made until the growth of modern densely populated cities in the 1800s. During this period, public health authorities began pressing for better waste disposal systems to be installed, to prevent or control epidemics of disease.. Only after 1945 most people in rural areas were connected to the water piping system as well.
Water companies were founded to ensure - still today - that water is suitable for consumption. The water is carried to the users by an extensive piping system. A sewage system ensures that the waste water is drained.

items.content:
Water companies deliver massive amounts of drinking water to their customers on a daily base.
A considerable amount of this water is pumped directly into the distribution network.
At times that the demand of consumers is very low, for example, during the night, the water is temporarily stored in reservoirs.

Clean water cellar


Purpose
To respond to peak consumption in such a way that the water purification can continue at a constant flow rate.
(Flow rate: the number of m³ of water that passes on a given point and per unit time).

Principle
Thanks to the clean water cellars we are able to build up a water supply from which we can draw when demand in the water supply system is bigger than the capacity of the water production.


Operation|
The filtered water comes through collectors in underground reservoirs. The water level in these reservoirs is monitored through automatic level measurements. As soon as the level in the clean water cellars has become too low, the water production is increased. When the water level has regained, the extra supply to the clean water cellars will stop. The water from these cellars is pumped in the distribution network by high pressure pumps.

High pressure pump

Purpose
Transport the purified drinking water to the customer and provide a constant pressure to the available water.

Principle
Through the use of high pressure pumps one can pump water from the clean water cellars to the water towers or directly in the distribution network.

Operation
The pumps send water under high pressure to the distribution pipes. They supply both the users directly and the water towers. The control of the high pressure pumps is based on the measured water pressure in the circuit and/or by the water level in water towers.

Water tower

Purpose
Ensure the supply of purified water close to the user and absorbing pressure surges and peak consumption. The water tower is thus both a flow rate and a pressure regulator.


Principle

Flow rate regulator
The water is pumped to the users and the water tower by high-pressure pumps. These pumps have a pretty constant flow rate. If the consumption of the customers is lower than the flow rate provided by the pumps, then the surplus is stored in the water tower. If the consumption is higher, then the deficit is complemented by the reserves from the water tower.

Pressure regulator
The difference in height between the water level in the tub and the water in the distribution pipes, creates a natural pressure due to gravity and the system of the "communicating vessels".

Operation
A water tower is not more than a reservoir or container that rests on a support. The tub usually has a double wall and the top is covered. In this way the temperature can be kept constant and the water is protected from pollution.

In principle, a water tower has just two pipes. The tub is filled from above by the input pipe. At the end is a valve that automatically shuts down as the float indicates that the tub is full. Through a grid in the bottom of the tub, the water is directed into the distribution pipe, after which it distributed to the customers. This is done by the natural law of gravity, without the aid of pumps or other installations. The supply and distribution can happen through the same pipe, or through two different. Important is that the supply and drainage are positioned in such a that the water in the tub is refreshed frequently.

In addition, there is always an overflow at the top of the tub. Should there be a problem with the automatic valve, then the water can still flow away. This overflow is connected to the sewer by means of the overflow pipe. This tube is also required to empty the tub, for example, during maintenance work.

How does one know how much water the tub contains?
The water towers are equipped with an automatic level measurement system that allows the amount of water in the tub can be measured. This measurement can be done in different ways.

Most recent method is the ultrasonic level measurement. A device that hangs above the tub and sends pulses (inaudible to the human ear), that are reflected by the surface of the water. These echoes are captured by a sensor and the water level of the Tower is calculated on the basis of the time difference between emitting and receiving the signals. This level data can be requested either via a direct phone line, or stand in direct connection with a computer that manages the filling of the tub.

follows. On the water drives a float which is connected through a cable to a mechanism of indication on a measurement bar down in the water tower. In a number of water towers one works also with detectors that are placed on certain distances in the tub. These detectors send the signal whether they are still in contact with water or not..

Another method is to place a clock at the bottom of the tub that measures the pressure of the water and calculates how much water is left in the cockpit accordingly. However, these level measurement methods are systematically replaced by the ultrasonic level measurement system.

items.content:
Where does the water that is discharged from a house eventually end up?
Water is essential for human, plant and animal. Water is the source for all life. Water is valuable to the body and the spirit, but also to the world around us.

Learning objectives

In this learning unit you will work on the learning objectives:

  • Mention the most important functions of water for the human body
  • Describe and valuate measures for sustainable use of water
  • Cooperation
  • Creativity

Assignment

You make (in pairs) a slogan about the value of water.

Time

For this learning unit you have 2.5 hours available

Water is an essential fuel for our body. A mature man must drink almost three litres of water (contained in food and beverages) daily. This quantity is indispensable. Without water we can survive up to a maximum of four days, while we would hold out much longer without food. Therefore, water is seen as the main feeding source. We have a billion people in the world that require a daily three-hour walk to get hold of it.

prompt.body: How many % on average of the human body is water?

values.value: Our body consists of an average of 70% water.

content.body: Our body consists of an average of 70% water.

prompt.body: What "parts" of our body contain the most water

values.value:
The blood and brain contain the most water.
Our blood contains 92% water and our brains 90%.

content.body:
The blood and brain contain the most water.
Our blood contains 92% water and our brains 90%.

prompt.body: Do your bones and teeth also contain water?

values.value: Yes, in our bones there is 22% water and 10% in our teeth.

content.body: Yes, in our bones there is 22% water and 10% in our teeth.

prompt.body:
The body needs water to function properly.
Name four functions of water in the body.

values.value:
The four functions of the water in the body are:

  • transporting vitamins, minerals and nutrients through the body,
  • the removal of waste,
  • strengthening the immune system and preventing disease,
  • controlling the body temperature.

content.body:
The four functions of the water in the body are:

  • transporting vitamins, minerals and nutrients through the body,
  • the removal of waste,
  • strengthening the immune system and preventing disease,
  • controlling the body temperature.

heading.content: Step 2 – How much water do you need?

header.title: How much water do you need?

prompt.body:
Daily we lose body fluids and we should always supplement this. The amount of liquid needed, varies from person to person. Children need more liquid than adults. The age and body weight and, of course, the physical activity determine the need for liquids. After all, somebody who is active loses more fluid through sweating and through breathing. Also the ambient temperature plays a role, so that it is difficult to determine the correct liquid requirement of an individual. 1 to 1.5 litres of water daily, and even more when we are sick, is advised to maintain or restore the balance in the body and mind.

The table below gives an impression of the recommended daily amount of liquid (water) per kilogram of body weight:

Babies 110 ml/kg
Children (up to 10 years old) 40 ml/kg
Adults 30 ml/kg
Elderly (above 65) 25 ml/kg

In practice, this means that a child of 6 years that weighs 20 kg. would need to drink 20 x 40 = 800 ml per day.

Calculate on the basis of the above table how many ml. of water you need to drink a day.

values.value:
To be judged by the teacher.

Example: a 13-year old student weighs 40 kg. According to the table, he must drink ± 35 ml / kg of water (the average of 40 and 30 ml / kg). Every day he must drink: 40 X 35 = 1400 ml. That is about 1½ liters of water (6-8 large glasses).

content.body:
To be judged by the teacher.

Example: a 13-year old student weighs 40 kg. According to the table, he must drink ± 35 ml / kg of water (the average of 40 and 30 ml / kg). Every day he must drink: 40 X 35 = 1400 ml. That is about 1½ liters of water (6-8 large glasses).

prompt.body:
If you sport or are on vacation in a "hot" country you need to drink more.
Why?

values.value: If you are sporting or on vacation in a "hot" country you will perspire much more. You lose more fluid, get thirsty and start drinking more.

content.body: If you are sporting or on vacation in a "hot" country you will perspire much more. You lose more fluid, get thirsty and start drinking more.

prompt.body: Why do you get thirsty?

values.value: When you are thirsty, it usually indicates that you have not drunk enough water. When the body secretes water, the saliva glands in the mouth release less saliva. This makes the mouth drier. This dryness of the mouth is experienced as thirsty.

content.body: When you are thirsty, it usually indicates that you have not drunk enough water. When the body secretes water, the saliva glands in the mouth release less saliva. This makes the mouth drier. This dryness of the mouth is experienced as thirsty.

prompt.body:
If you have a shortage of moisture in the tissues you can determine that yourself.
What are the early signs of a deficiency of moisture in your tissue?

values.value:
The first signs of a lack of fluid in your tissue are usually: thirst and urine that is dark in color (due to the concentration of waste products). The body can give out different signals if you drink too little:

  • Headache: water removes toxins from the body. The brain consists of 75% water. So even if you are just a little bit dehydrated, you can already get a headache.
  • Fatigue / poor concentration: if the body needs all its strength to remove the excess of toxins as a result of insufficient drinking, you will have less energy.
  • Constipation: water speeds up and relaxes the relief process. By drinking enough you get a regular bowel movement.
  • Little or dark urine: the kidneys filter waste products from the blood. This requires water. Otherwise, urine production will decrease and the concentration of waste products will increase. You immediately see this on the dark color of the urine.
  • Bad breath: If not enough water flows through the mouth to wash away all food remains, bacteria accumulate in the mouth and pharynx. The tongue becomes white, and bad breath is the result.
  • Dry mouth: saliva is the natural lubrication of the mouth. If you drink too little, the body makes less saliva and you get a dry mouth.
  • Dry skin: If you drink too little, the skin becomes less elastic. You can check this by pulling up the skin on the back of your hand. If you let go of the skin, the skin must immediately shoot back.
  • Inflated appearance: the less you drink, the more the body stores water as a reserve supply. As a result, the cells swell and you look 'too fat'.

  • Fatigue / poor concentration: if the body needs all its strength to remove the excess of toxins as a result of insufficient drinking, you will have less energy.
  • Constipation: water speeds up and relaxes the relief process. By drinking enough you get a regular bowel movement.

prompt.body:
The body of an adult needs about 3 litres of water per day in normal conditions.
How does an adult obtain this amount of water in the body?

values.value: The body of an adult needs about 3 liters of water per day in normal circumstances. Every day the body absorbs 0.9 to 1 liter of water from food. Another 0.3 to 0.4 liters of water will be available during the metabolic process. The remaining one and a half liters of water comes through drinking in the body.

content.body: The body of an adult needs about 3 liters of water per day in normal circumstances. Every day the body absorbs 0.9 to 1 liter of water from food. Another 0.3 to 0.4 liters of water will be available during the metabolic process. The remaining one and a half liters of water comes through drinking in the body.

prompt.body:
About 3 litres of clean water should enter in the body and about 3 litres of contaminated water should leave the body daily.
In which ways does the water leave the body?

values.value: Approximately 3 liters of contaminated water should be drained out of the body every day: 1.6 to 1.8 liters leave the body as urine; 0.2 liters is in the stool; 0.5 liters is excreted in the form of perspiration and 0.4 liters in the form of steam.

content.body: Approximately 3 liters of contaminated water should be drained out of the body every day: 1.6 to 1.8 liters leave the body as urine; 0.2 liters is in the stool; 0.5 liters is excreted in the form of perspiration and 0.4 liters in the form of steam.

prompt.body:
Minerals are important for health. As an example: without the help of minerals vitamins cannot function in our body. Minerals transport oxygen around our bodies. They also play an important role in the growth, maintenance and repair of tissues. Minerals are also involved in the contraction of muscles, the functioning of the nerves and energy management. The following minerals are found in our tap water:

  • Sodium is important for managing the water balance, the functioning of muscles and nerves - and transports the food.
  • hloride with sodium and potassium is responsible for maintaining the equilibrium of the water balance. It is an ingredient of gastric juices for digestion.
  • otassium along with sodium and chloride regulates the water balance and the functioning of muscles and nerves.
  • alcium is essential for building and maintenance of bones and teeth. Calcium is also important in blood clotting, the functioning of nerves and muscles and transport of substances (sodium, potassium and magnesium) in and out the body cells.
  • hosphorus is also an important constituent of bones and teeth and also needed for the construction of enzymes. It helps in energy generation and is a building block of cell nucleus acids.
  • agnesium is needed for bone growth and plays an important role in the construction of body protein and the transmission of nerve impulses.
  • ron contributes to the formation of red blood cells and is responsible for the collection and release of oxygen in the blood.
  • inc is a component of many enzymes in the body. It has an important function at renewal of tissue and the functioning of the immune system.
  • •odine is a building block of the thyroid hormones. These hormones are essential for proper growth, development of the nervous system and the maintenance of the metabolism in the body.

Take the label of a bottle of spring or mineral water.
Compare the minerals from tap water to that of source- or mineral water.
Is bottled water healthier than tap water?

values.value:
To be judged by the teacher.

As an example, we give the average composition in mg. per liter of the substances contained in one liter of spring water from the "Perrier" brand.

Cl Chloride
NO3   Nitrate
Mg Magnesium
SO4 Sulphate
Na Sodium
HCO3   Bicarbonate
Ca Calcium  
F Fluoride
K Potassium

 

Virtually the same substances occur both in tap water and in spring water. Conclusion: tap water is just as healthy as bottled water.

content.body:
To be judged by the teacher.

As an example, we give the average composition in mg. per liter of the substances contained in one liter of spring water from the "Perrier" brand.

Cl Chloride
NO3 Nitrate
Mg Magnesium
SO4 Sulphate
Na Sodium
HCO3 Bicarbonate
Ca Calcium
F Fluoride
K Potassium

Virtually the same substances occur both in tap water and in spring water. Conclusion: tap water is just as healthy as bottled water.

prompt.body: Is bottled water tastier than tap water?

values.value: What is better? It is a matter of taste and that is difficult to discuss. One finds bottled water tastier because it contains more salts or some carbon dioxide. With others it is just the other way around. Most people do not even taste the difference when bottled and tap water have the same temperature and contain as many salts.

content.body: What is better? It is a matter of taste and that is difficult to discuss. One finds bottled water tastier because it contains more salts or some carbon dioxide. With others it is just the other way around. Most people do not even taste the difference when bottled and tap water have the same temperature and contain as many salts.

heading.content: Step 4 - Water in industry and agriculture

prompt.body:
Of all the water that is distributed, the households account for about 37- to 40%. The rest goes to industry and agriculture.
What is water used for in industry?

values.value: In industry, water is used as raw material (e.g.in beer breweries), auxiliary material (e.g. in papermaking), refrigerant (e.g. at steel plants) and flushing agent. Transport (of, for example, raw materials or products) still takes place largely over water.

content.body: In industry, water is used as raw material (e.g.in beer breweries), auxiliary material (e.g. in papermaking), refrigerant (e.g. at steel plants) and flushing agent. Transport (of, for example, raw materials or products) still takes place largely over water.

prompt.body: By whom is water used in agriculture?

values.value: In agriculture, water is used by the arable farmer, the livestock farmer and the horticulturist. After all, plants and animals need water.

content.body: In agriculture, water is used by the arable farmer, the livestock farmer and the horticulturist. After all, plants and animals need water.

prompt.body:
Other than households, industry and agriculture, water is also used for other purposes.
Give one example.

values.value: Water is also used in a swimming pool or for fountains.

content.body: Water is also used in a swimming pool or for fountains.

prompt.body:
Drinking water can be contaminated with the legionella bacteria.
Do you become sick if you drink this water?

values.value: No, you do not get sick when you drink water contaminated with the legionella bacteria.

content.body: No, you do not get sick when you drink water contaminated with the legionella bacteria.

prompt.body: What is Legionnaires ' disease and how do you get that?

values.value:
Veterans' disease is caused by the legionella bacterium. The symptoms can vary from a severe cold to a severe flu with pneumonia.

Contamination takes place via the lungs. Infection takes place by inhaling the bacteria in very small drops of water, dispersed in the air (aerosols). The disease can not be transferred from one person to another and is not contagious. Drinking water contaminated with legionella is not a risk.

content.body:
Veterans' disease is caused by the legionella bacterium. The symptoms can vary from a severe cold to a severe flu with pneumonia.

Contamination takes place via the lungs. Infection takes place by inhaling the bacteria in very small drops of water, dispersed in the air (aerosols). The disease can not be transferred from one person to another and is not contagious. Drinking water contaminated with legionella is not a risk.

prompt.body: Can you also get Legionnaires ' disease get by drinking water of the boiler?

values.value: The legionella bacterium is the cause of the so-called Legionnaires disease. The bacterium multiplies in hot water appliances with a storage tank (such as boilers) at temperatures between 20 and 50 degrees Celsius. If your water heater is set to a temperature of 60 degrees Celsius or more, you do not run any risk. The bacteria are then killed.

content.body: The legionella bacterium is the cause of the so-called Legionnaires disease. The bacterium multiplies in hot water appliances with a storage tank (such as boilers) at temperatures between 20 and 50 degrees Celsius. If your water heater is set to a temperature of 60 degrees Celsius or more, you do not run any risk. The bacteria are then killed.

prompt.body: Can you drink hot water from the tap?

values.value: No, you better don't do that. Because heated water can contain extra (and sometimes even too much) metals. The water company can only guarantee the quality of cold tap water. Of course you can drink hot water, which is first cooked. Tea or cooled water are therefore no problem.

content.body: No, you better don't do that. Because heated water can contain extra (and sometimes even too much) metals. The water company can only guarantee the quality of cold tap water. Of course you can drink hot water, which is first cooked. Tea or cooled water are therefore no problem.

prompt.body: Can you drink "grey" water?

values.value: No, you can not drink "gray" water. "Gray" water is lightly contaminated waste water from bath, shower, sink and possibly washing machine. This water is contaminated with soap residue, making it gray in color after some time. Gray water can be used after (local) purification for toilet flushing, washing, cleaning and in the garden.

content.body: No, you can not drink "gray" water. "Gray" water is lightly contaminated waste water from bath, shower, sink and possibly washing machine. This water is contaminated with soap residue, making it gray in color after some time. Gray water can be used after (local) purification for toilet flushing, washing, cleaning and in the garden.

prompt.body: Can you drink "brown" water?

values.value: The brown color of the water is caused by rust particles (iron and manganese). The rust particles are not harmful to health. You can therefore simply drink the water.

content.body: The brown color of the water is caused by rust particles (iron and manganese). The rust particles are not harmful to health. You can therefore simply drink the water.

prompt.body: Can you lose weight with water?

values.value: Yes, water naturally removes the appetite. Conversely, too little drinking can lead to too much food. The brain does not distinguish between hunger and thirst. A hungry feeling can actually just be thirsty. If you drink a lot of water, you feel full faster and you have less appetite for food. That is why it is smart to drink two or three glasses of water for every meal.

content.body: Yes, water naturally removes the appetite. Conversely, too little drinking can lead to too much food. The brain does not distinguish between hunger and thirst. A hungry feeling can actually just be thirsty. If you drink a lot of water, you feel full faster and you have less appetite for food. That is why it is smart to drink two or three glasses of water for every meal.

questions.label: What should you do with old oil or turpentine?

prompt.body:
To flush oil in the sewer pit or turpentine by the sink is bad for the environment.
One litre of oil that ends up in the groundwater, can make a million litres of water unsuitable for consumption.
What should you do with oil or turpentine when you can no longer use it?

values.value: Turpentine and oil do not belong in the sewer. They belong to small chemical waste. In most cities you can dispose of small chemical waste at special places like a local hazardous waste disposal service.

content.body: Turpentine and oil do not belong in the sewer. They belong to small chemical waste. In most cities you can dispose of small chemical waste at special places like a local hazardous waste disposal service.

prompt.body:
GCS The Government Communication Service (https://gcs.civilservice.gov.uk/) wants to start a campaign on the "value of water".

You are asked to think of a catchy slogan for the campaign.

Brainstorm with a classmate for a slogan. You both enter the slogan in the field below..

values.value:
• A slogan is short and concise and often has an alliteration or rhyme in it, but that is not necessarily necessary.
  • GCS wants to encourage people to think, make difficult things negotiable, stimulate the debate and get people moving. Your slogan should help.

content.body:
• A slogan is short and concise and often has an alliteration or rhyme in it, but that is not necessarily necessary.
  • GCS wants to encourage people to think, make difficult things negotiable, stimulate the debate and get people moving. Your slogan should help.

items.content:
You are going to complete the drinking water module.

You are going to do the final assignment on drinking water in a group.
The groups are composed by your teacher in consultation with you.

In the final assignment you integrate the learning objectives to which you so far in this module have been working.

You can choose, as a group, one of the following subjects for your final assignments:



The water magazine

Make an illustrated door-to-door magazine of the drinking water company with articles and interviews about drinking water.
Use the content of the different exercises in this module.
You will be judged on content, layout and readability of the water magazine.


The water-rap

Make a rap that will convince young people to act responsible with water. As it is supposed to be with a rap, it´s sometimes just on or over the edge.
You will be judged on creativity, content and persuasiveness of the rap and of course on a good beat.



The mini water purification plant

Create a working water purification plant by using materials of school (Science), which may eventually be supplemented with own or purchased materials. The installation must be able to purify one glass of water from the ditch into responsibly drinkable water. You will be assessed on the principle and the implementation of the installation and the explanation of the operation. And of course there is a bonus point if you drink the purified water yourself.


Own assignment

Do you have a much better, more interesting, more beautiful or more important final assignment about drinking water in mind? Consult it with your teacher - and if it - in terms of depth and amount of work - corresponds to a suitable final assignment (about drinking water of course), then it is definitely approved.
Assessment criteria for your end product will be determined in consultation with the teacher.

introduction.body:

  2. Een tijdplan:

  3. Een materialenlijst:
    Je geeft aan welke materialen je voor het eindproduct nodig hebt en waar je ze vandaan haalt. Eventueel ook wat ze kosten.

colophon.title: Over dit lesmateriaal
colophon.description:
Dit arrangement is gebaseerd op materiaal in Word formaat van Digischool.

Het sluit aan op de leerdoelen waterbewustzijn en waterbewust gedrag uit het  curriculumvoorstel Watereducatie van het SLO (2012).

Daarnaast sluit het aan op de volgende kerndoelen:

Aardrijkskunde (HAVO) - Maatregelen voor duurzaam watergebruik beschrijven en waarderen - Oplossingen aandragen om duurzaam watergebruik te bevorderen - De verschillende fasen van de waterkringloop beschrijven en verklaren

Biologie (Havo) - Benoemen van de belnagrijkste functies van [...] en water voor het lichaam

Scheikunde - Bij de naam van [10] moleculaire stoffen de formule weergeven en omgekeerd

Natuur- en scheikunde (VMBO KGT) - Kringloop van water beschrijven - Productie en distributie van drinkwater beschrijven
